definition: to cheat/to swindle/to pretend/to feign/to draw sb out/to try to extract information by deceit or bluff

sentences.english: A follower of the bandit landlord Ko Tseng-chiang, he kidnaped people for ransom, stole goods and plundered land.
sentences.chinese: 他绑架诈取赎金，偷东西，还强占别人土地。

sentences.english: The dishonest manager defrauded the company of millions of pounds.
sentences.chinese: 这个不诚实的经理诈取了公司几百万英镑。

sentences.english: He defrauded his employers of thousands of dollars.
sentences.chinese: 他诈取了他的雇主一大笔钱。

sentences.english: Old William usually manages to sponge a drink off somebody in the pub.
sentences.chinese: 老威廉常常设法诈取酒客的钱。

sentences.english: He pretended to be a journalist, and swindled lots of money.
sentences.chinese: 冒充记者招摇撞骗，诈取了不少钱财。

sentences.english: Zacchaeus had gotten rich because he knew how to get more than his fair share of things.
sentences.chinese: 撒该之所以成为富有，是因为他知道如何诈取金钱。

sentences.english: The clever salesman was able to trick the old lady out of her money with his charm.
sentences.chinese: 这精明的推销商施展魅力诈取了老太太的钱。

sentences.english: He came with intent to defraud.
sentences.chinese: 他怀着诈取钱财的目的而来。

sentences.english: He got money from me by a trick.
sentences.chinese: 他从我这里诈取到了那笔钱。

sentences.english: They swindled that sucker out of his money.

definition: to scam/to set a trap/to set up a scheme to defraud people
to fabricate excuses (idiom)/to concoct various items (e.g. to pad an expense account)
to extort under false pretenses/to blackmail/to bluff/to defraud
to entice/to lure/to scam/to hoodwink/to decoy
